page.title: 16CLOSURE OF PUMPING STATION
page.content: At Drellingore on the B2060 stood a Victorian two storey pumping station. It was demolished in October 1981 to the annoyance of local industrial archaeologists. The building was said to be one of the finest examples of industrial architecture in the area. Dover Transport Museum Society tried to lease the building to display steam and petrol driven engines but the Folkestone and District Water Company rejected the idea due to fears that water wells underneath would become polluted. A modern pumping station has been built nearby and a new reservoir tank erected at Chalksole. Drellingore is the source of the River Dour which flows through Dover and legend has it that when the "woe-waters" of Drellingore flood Alkhams cricket pitch as in 20/01/67 a national disaster will occur.
